Files

minijinja/value/
mod.rs

1//! Provides a dynamic value type abstraction.
2//!
3//! This module gives access to a dynamically typed value which is used by
4//! the template engine during execution.
5//!
6//! For the most part the existence of the value type can be ignored as
7//! MiniJinja will perform the necessary conversions for you.  For instance
8//! if you write a filter that converts a string you can directly declare the
9//! filter to take a [`String`](std::string::String).  However for some more
10//! advanced use cases it's useful to know that this type exists.
11//!
12//! # Basic Value Conversions
13//!
14//! Values are typically created via the [`From`] trait:
15//!
16//! ```
17//! # use minijinja::value::Value;
18//! let int_value = Value::from(42);
19//! let none_value = Value::from(());
20//! let true_value = Value::from(true);
21//! ```
22//!
23//! Or via the [`FromIterator`] trait:
24//!
25//! ```
26//! # use minijinja::value::Value;
27//!
28//! // collection into a sequence
29//! let value: Value = (1..10).into_iter().collect();
30//!
31//! // collection into a map
32//! let value: Value = [("key", "value")].into_iter().collect();
33//! ```
34//!
35//! For certain types of iterators (`Send` + `Sync` + `'static`) it's also
36//! possible to make the value lazily iterate over the value by using the
37//! `Value::make_one_shot_iterator` function instead:
38//!
39//! ```
40//! # use minijinja::value::Value;
41//! let value: Value = Value::make_one_shot_iterator(1..10);
42//! ```
43//!
44//! To to into the inverse directly the various [`TryFrom`](std::convert::TryFrom)
45//! implementations can be used:
46//!
47//! ```
48//! # use minijinja::value::Value;
49//! use std::convert::TryFrom;
50//! let v = u64::try_from(Value::from(42)).unwrap();
51//! ```
52//!
53//! The special [`Undefined`](Value::UNDEFINED) value also exists but does not
54//! have a rust equivalent.  It can be created via the [`UNDEFINED`](Value::UNDEFINED)
55//! constant.
56//!
57//! # Serde Conversions
58//!
59//! MiniJinja will usually however create values via an indirection via [`serde`] when
60//! a template is rendered or an expression is evaluated.  This can also be
61//! triggered manually by using the [`Value::from_serialize`] method:
62//!
63//! ```
64//! # use minijinja::value::Value;
65//! let value = Value::from_serialize(&[1, 2, 3]);
66//! ```
67//!
68//! The inverse of that operation is to pass a value directly as serializer to
69//! a type that supports deserialization.  This requires the `deserialization`
70//! feature.
71//!
72#![cfg_attr(
73    feature = "deserialization",
74    doc = r"
75```
76# use minijinja::value::Value;
77use serde::Deserialize;
78let value = Value::from(vec![1, 2, 3]);
79let vec = Vec::<i32>::deserialize(value).unwrap();
80```
81"
82)]
83//!
84//! # Value Function Arguments
85//!
86//! [Filters](crate::filters) and [tests](crate::tests) can take values as arguments
87//! but optionally also rust types directly.  This conversion for function arguments
88//! is performed by the [`FunctionArgs`] and related traits ([`ArgType`], [`FunctionResult`]).
89//!
90//! # Memory Management
91//!
92//! Values are immutable objects which are internally reference counted which
93//! means they can be copied relatively cheaply.  Special care must be taken
94//! so that cycles are not created to avoid causing memory leaks.
95//!
96//! # HTML Escaping
97//!
98//! MiniJinja inherits the general desire to be clever about escaping.  For this
99//! purpose a value will (when auto escaping is enabled) always be escaped.  To
100//! prevent this behavior the [`safe`](crate::filters::safe) filter can be used
101//! in the template.  Outside of templates the [`Value::from_safe_string`] method
102//! can be used to achieve the same result.
103//!
104//! # Dynamic Objects
105//!
106//! Values can also hold "dynamic" objects.  These are objects which implement the
107//! [`Object`] trait and optionally [`SeqObject`] or [`StructObject`]  These can
108//! be used to implement dynamic functionality such as stateful values and more.
109//! Dynamic objects are internally also used to implement the special `loop`
110//! variable or macros.
111//!
112//! To create a dynamic `Value` object, use [`Value::from_object`],
113//! [`Value::from_seq_object`], [`Value::from_struct_object`] or the `From<Arc<T:
114//! Object>>` implementations for `Value`:
115//!
116//! ```rust
117//! # use std::sync::Arc;
118//! # use minijinja::value::{Value, Object};
119//! #[derive(Debug)]
120//! struct Foo;
121//!
122//! # impl std::fmt::Display for Foo {
123//! #     fn fmt(&self, f: &mut std::fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> std::fmt::Result { Ok(()) }
124//! # }
125//! #
126//! impl Object for Foo {
127//!     /* implementation */
128//! }
129//!
130//! let value = Value::from_object(Foo);
131//! let value = Value::from(Arc::new(Foo));
132//! let value = Value::from(Arc::new(Foo) as Arc<dyn Object>);
133//! ```
134
135// this module is based on the content module in insta which in turn is based
136// on the content module in serde::private::ser.
137

177// We use in-band signalling to roundtrip some internal values.  This is
178// not ideal but unfortunately there is no better system in serde today.
179const VALUE_HANDLE_MARKER: &str = "\x01__minijinja_ValueHandle";
180
181#[cfg(feature = "preserve_order")]
182pub(crate) type ValueMap = indexmap::IndexMap<KeyRef<'static>, Value>;
183
184#[cfg(not(feature = "preserve_order"))]
185pub(crate) type ValueMap = std::collections::BTreeMap<KeyRef<'static>, Value>;
186
187#[inline(always)]
188pub(crate) fn value_map_with_capacity(capacity: usize) -> ValueMap {
189    #[cfg(not(feature = "preserve_order"))]
190    {
191        let _ = capacity;
192        ValueMap::new()
193    }
194    #[cfg(feature = "preserve_order")]
195    {
196        ValueMap::with_capacity(crate::utils::untrusted_size_hint(capacity))
197    }
198}
199
200thread_local! {
201    static INTERNAL_SERIALIZATION: Cell<bool> = const { Cell::new(false) };
202
203    // This should be an AtomicU64 but sadly 32bit targets do not necessarily have
204    // AtomicU64 available.
205    static LAST_VALUE_HANDLE: Cell<u32> = const { Cell::new(0) };
206    static VALUE_HANDLES: RefCell<BTreeMap<u32, Value>> = RefCell::new(BTreeMap::new());
207}
208
209/// Function that returns true when serialization for [`Value`] is taking place.
210///
211/// MiniJinja internally creates [`Value`] objects from all values passed to the
212/// engine.  It does this by going through the regular serde serialization trait.
213/// In some cases users might want to customize the serialization specifically for
214/// MiniJinja because they want to tune the object for the template engine
215/// independently of what is normally serialized to disk.
216///
217/// This function returns `true` when MiniJinja is serializing to [`Value`] and
218/// `false` otherwise.  You can call this within your own [`Serialize`]
219/// implementation to change the output format.
220///
221/// This is particularly useful as serialization for MiniJinja does not need to
222/// support deserialization.  So it becomes possible to completely change what
223/// gets sent there, even at the cost of serializing something that cannot be
224/// deserialized.
225pub fn serializing_for_value() -> bool {
226    INTERNAL_SERIALIZATION.with(|flag| flag.get())
227}
228
229/// Enables value optimizations.
230///
231/// If `key_interning` is enabled, this turns on that feature, otherwise
232/// it becomes a noop.
233#[inline(always)]
234pub(crate) fn value_optimization() -> impl Drop {
235    #[cfg(feature = "key_interning")]
236    {
237        crate::value::keyref::key_interning::use_string_cache()
238    }
239    #[cfg(not(feature = "key_interning"))]
240    {
241        OnDrop::new(|| {})
242    }
243}
244
245fn mark_internal_serialization() -> impl Drop {
246    let old = INTERNAL_SERIALIZATION.with(|flag| {
247        let old = flag.get();
248        flag.set(true);
249        old
250    });
251    OnDrop::new(move || {
252        if !old {
253            INTERNAL_SERIALIZATION.with(|flag| flag.set(false));
254        }
255    })
256}
257
258/// Describes the kind of value.
259#[derive(Copy, Clone, Debug, Eq, PartialEq, Ord, PartialOrd)]
260pub enum ValueKind {
261    /// The value is undefined
262    Undefined,
263    /// The value is the none singleton ([`()`])
264    None,
265    /// The value is a [`bool`]
266    Bool,
267    /// The value is a number of a supported type.
268    Number,
269    /// The value is a string.
270    String,
271    /// The value is a byte array.
272    Bytes,
273    /// The value is an array of other values.
274    Seq,
275    /// The value is a key/value mapping.
276    Map,
277}
278
279impl fmt::Display for ValueKind {
280    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
281        f.write_str(match *self {
282            ValueKind::Undefined => "undefined",
283            ValueKind::None => "none",
284            ValueKind::Bool => "bool",
285            ValueKind::Number => "number",
286            ValueKind::String => "string",
287            ValueKind::Bytes => "bytes",
288            ValueKind::Seq => "sequence",
289            ValueKind::Map => "map",
290        })
291    }
292}
293
294/// The type of map
295#[derive(Copy, Clone, Debug)]
296pub(crate) enum MapType {
297    /// A regular map
298    Normal,
299    /// A map representing keyword arguments
300    Kwargs,
301}
302
303/// Type type of string
304#[derive(Copy, Clone, Debug)]
305pub(crate) enum StringType {
306    Normal,
307    Safe,
308}
309
310/// Wraps an internal copyable value but marks it as packed.
311///
312/// This is used for `i128`/`u128` in the value repr to avoid
313/// the excessive 16 byte alignment.
314#[derive(Copy)]
315#[repr(packed)]
316pub(crate) struct Packed<T: Copy>(pub T);
317
318impl<T: Copy> Clone for Packed<T> {
319    fn clone(&self) -> Self {
320        *self
321    }
322}
323
324#[derive(Clone)]
325pub(crate) enum ValueRepr {
326    Undefined,
327    Bool(bool),
328    U64(u64),
329    I64(i64),
330    F64(f64),
331    None,
332    Invalid(Arc<str>),
333    U128(Packed<u128>),
334    I128(Packed<i128>),
335    String(Arc<str>, StringType),
336    Bytes(Arc<Vec<u8>>),
337    Seq(Arc<Vec<Value>>),
338    Map(Arc<ValueMap>, MapType),
339    Dynamic(Arc<dyn Object>),
340}
341
342impl fmt::Debug for ValueRepr {
343    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
344        match self {
345            ValueRepr::Undefined => f.write_str("undefined"),
346            ValueRepr::Bool(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
347            ValueRepr::U64(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
348            ValueRepr::I64(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
349            ValueRepr::F64(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
350            ValueRepr::None => f.write_str("none"),
351            ValueRepr::Invalid(ref val) => write!(f, "<invalid value: {}>", val),
352            ValueRepr::U128(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(&{ val.0 }, f),
353            ValueRepr::I128(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(&{ val.0 }, f),
354            ValueRepr::String(val, _) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
355            ValueRepr::Bytes(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
356            ValueRepr::Seq(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
357            ValueRepr::Map(val, _) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
358            ValueRepr::Dynamic(val) => fmt::Debug::fmt(val, f),
359        }
360    }
361}
362
363impl Hash for Value {
364    fn hash<H: Hasher>(&self, state: &mut H) {
365        match &self.0 {
366            ValueRepr::None | ValueRepr::Undefined => 0u8.hash(state),
367            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => s.hash(state),
368            ValueRepr::Bool(b) => b.hash(state),
369            ValueRepr::Invalid(s) => s.hash(state),
370            ValueRepr::Bytes(b) => b.hash(state),
371            ValueRepr::Seq(b) => b.hash(state),
372            ValueRepr::Map(m, _) => m.iter().for_each(|(k, v)| {
373                k.hash(state);
374                v.hash(state);
375            }),
376            ValueRepr::Dynamic(d) => match d.kind() {
377                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => 0u8.hash(state),
378                ObjectKind::Seq(s) => s.iter().for_each(|x| x.hash(state)),
379                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => {
380                    if let Some(fields) = s.static_fields() {
381                        fields.iter().for_each(|k| {
382                            k.hash(state);
383                            s.get_field(k).hash(state);
384                        });
385                    } else {
386                        s.fields().iter().for_each(|k| {
387                            k.hash(state);
388                            s.get_field(k).hash(state);
389                        });
390                    }
391                }
392            },
393            ValueRepr::U64(_)
394            | ValueRepr::I64(_)
395            | ValueRepr::F64(_)
396            | ValueRepr::U128(_)
397            | ValueRepr::I128(_) => {
398                if let Ok(val) = i64::try_from(self.clone()) {
399                    val.hash(state)
400                } else {
401                    as_f64(self).map(|x| x.to_bits()).hash(state)
402                }
403            }
404        }
405    }
406}
407
408/// Represents a dynamically typed value in the template engine.
409#[derive(Clone)]
410pub struct Value(pub(crate) ValueRepr);
411
412impl PartialEq for Value {
413    fn eq(&self, other: &Self) -> bool {
414        match (&self.0, &other.0) {
415            (ValueRepr::None, ValueRepr::None) => true,
416            (ValueRepr::Undefined, ValueRepr::Undefined) => true,
417            (ValueRepr::String(ref a, _), ValueRepr::String(ref b, _)) => a == b,
418            (ValueRepr::Bytes(a), ValueRepr::Bytes(b)) => a == b,
419            _ => match ops::coerce(self, other) {
420                Some(ops::CoerceResult::F64(a, b)) => a == b,
421                Some(ops::CoerceResult::I128(a, b)) => a == b,
422                Some(ops::CoerceResult::Str(a, b)) => a == b,
423                None => {
424                    if let (Some(a), Some(b)) = (self.as_seq(), other.as_seq()) {
425                        a.iter().eq(b.iter())
426                    } else if self.kind() == ValueKind::Map && other.kind() == ValueKind::Map {
427                        if self.len() != other.len() {
428                            return false;
429                        }
430                        if let Ok(mut iter) = self.try_iter() {
431                            iter.all(|x| self.get_item_opt(&x) == other.get_item_opt(&x))
432                        } else {
433                            false
434                        }
435                    } else {
436                        false
437                    }
438                }
439            },
440        }
441    }
442}
443
444impl Eq for Value {}
445
446impl PartialOrd for Value {
447    fn partial_cmp(&self, other: &Self) -> Option<Ordering> {
448        Some(self.cmp(other))
449    }
450}
451
452fn f64_total_cmp(left: f64, right: f64) -> Ordering {
453    // this is taken from f64::total_cmp on newer rust versions
454    let mut left = left.to_bits() as i64;
455    let mut right = right.to_bits() as i64;
456    left ^= (((left >> 63) as u64) >> 1) as i64;
457    right ^= (((right >> 63) as u64) >> 1) as i64;
458    left.cmp(&right)
459}
460
461impl Ord for Value {
462    fn cmp(&self, other: &Self) -> Ordering {
463        let value_ordering = match (&self.0, &other.0) {
464            (ValueRepr::None, ValueRepr::None) => Ordering::Equal,
465            (ValueRepr::Undefined, ValueRepr::Undefined) => Ordering::Equal,
466            (ValueRepr::String(ref a, _), ValueRepr::String(ref b, _)) => a.cmp(b),
467            (ValueRepr::Bytes(a), ValueRepr::Bytes(b)) => a.cmp(b),
468            _ => match ops::coerce(self, other) {
469                Some(ops::CoerceResult::F64(a, b)) => f64_total_cmp(a, b),
470                Some(ops::CoerceResult::I128(a, b)) => a.cmp(&b),
471                Some(ops::CoerceResult::Str(a, b)) => a.cmp(b),
472                None => {
473                    if let (Some(a), Some(b)) = (self.as_seq(), other.as_seq()) {
474                        a.iter().cmp(b.iter())
475                    } else if self.kind() == ValueKind::Map && other.kind() == ValueKind::Map {
476                        if let (Ok(a), Ok(b)) = (self.try_iter(), other.try_iter()) {
477                            a.map(|k| (k.clone(), self.get_item_opt(&k)))
478                                .cmp(b.map(|k| (k.clone(), other.get_item_opt(&k))))
479                        } else {
480                            Ordering::Equal
481                        }
482                    } else {
483                        Ordering::Equal
484                    }
485                }
486            },
487        };
488        value_ordering.then((self.kind() as usize).cmp(&(other.kind() as usize)))
489    }
490}
491
492impl fmt::Debug for Value {
493    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> Result<(), std::fmt::Error> {
494        fmt::Debug::fmt(&self.0, f)
495    }
496}
497
498impl fmt::Display for Value {
499    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
500        match &self.0 {
501            ValueRepr::Undefined => Ok(()),
502            ValueRepr::Bool(val) => val.fmt(f),
503            ValueRepr::U64(val) => val.fmt(f),
504            ValueRepr::I64(val) => val.fmt(f),
505            ValueRepr::F64(val) => {
506                if val.is_nan() {
507                    f.write_str("NaN")
508                } else if val.is_infinite() {
509                    write!(f, "{}inf", if val.is_sign_negative() { "-" } else { "" })
510                } else {
511                    let mut num = val.to_string();
512                    if !num.contains('.') {
513                        num.push_str(".0");
514                    }
515                    write!(f, "{num}")
516                }
517            }
518            ValueRepr::None => f.write_str("none"),
519            ValueRepr::Invalid(ref val) => write!(f, "<invalid value: {}>", val),
520            ValueRepr::I128(val) => write!(f, "{}", { val.0 }),
521            ValueRepr::String(val, _) => write!(f, "{val}"),
522            ValueRepr::Bytes(val) => write!(f, "{}", String::from_utf8_lossy(val)),
523            ValueRepr::Seq(values) => {
524                ok!(f.write_str("["));
525                for (idx, val) in values.iter().enumerate() {
526                    if idx > 0 {
527                        ok!(f.write_str(", "));
528                    }
529                    ok!(write!(f, "{val:?}"));
530                }
531                f.write_str("]")
532            }
533            ValueRepr::Map(m, _) => {
534                ok!(f.write_str("{"));
535                for (idx, (key, val)) in m.iter().enumerate() {
536                    if idx > 0 {
537                        ok!(f.write_str(", "));
538                    }
539                    ok!(write!(f, "{key:?}: {val:?}"));
540                }
541                f.write_str("}")
542            }
543            ValueRepr::U128(val) => write!(f, "{}", { val.0 }),
544            ValueRepr::Dynamic(x) => write!(f, "{x}"),
545        }
546    }
547}
548
549impl Default for Value {
550    fn default() -> Value {
551        ValueRepr::Undefined.into()
552    }
553}
554
555/// Intern a string.
556///
557/// When the `key_interning` feature is in used, then MiniJinja will attempt to
558/// reuse strings in certain cases.  This function can be used to utilize the
559/// same functionality.  There is no guarantee that a string will be interned
560/// as there are heuristics involved for it.  Additionally the string interning
561/// will only work during the template engine execution (eg: within filters etc.).
562pub fn intern(s: &str) -> Arc<str> {
563    #[cfg(feature = "key_interning")]
564    {
565        crate::value::keyref::key_interning::try_intern(s)
566    }
567    #[cfg(not(feature = "key_interning"))]
568    {
569        Arc::from(s.to_string())
570    }
571}
572
573#[allow(clippy::len_without_is_empty)]
574impl Value {
575    /// The undefined value.
576    ///
577    /// This constant exists because the undefined type does not exist in Rust
578    /// and this is the only way to construct it.
579    pub const UNDEFINED: Value = Value(ValueRepr::Undefined);
580
581    /// Creates a value from something that can be serialized.
582    ///
583    /// This is the method that MiniJinja will generally use whenever a serializable
584    /// object is passed to one of the APIs that internally want to create a value.
585    /// For instance this is what [`context!`](crate::context) and
586    /// [`render`](crate::Template::render) will use.
587    ///
588    /// During serialization of the value, [`serializing_for_value`] will return
589    /// `true` which makes it possible to customize serialization for MiniJinja.
590    /// For more information see [`serializing_for_value`].
591    ///
592    /// ```
593    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
594    /// let val = Value::from_serialize(&vec![1, 2, 3]);
595    /// ```
596    ///
597    /// This method does not fail but it might return a value that is not valid.  Such
598    /// values will when operated on fail in the template engine in most situations.
599    /// This for instance can happen if the underlying implementation of [`Serialize`]
600    /// fails.  There are also cases where invalid objects are silently hidden in the
601    /// engine today.  This is for instance the case for when keys are used in hash maps
602    /// that the engine cannot deal with.  Invalid values are considered an implementation
603    /// detail.  There is currently no API to validate a value.
604    ///
605    /// If the `deserialization` feature is enabled then the inverse of this method
606    /// is to use the [`Value`] type as serializer.  You can pass a value into the
607    /// [`deserialize`](serde::Deserialize::deserialize) method of a type that supports
608    /// serde deserialization.
609    pub fn from_serialize<T: Serialize>(value: T) -> Value {
610        let _serialization_guard = mark_internal_serialization();
611        let _optimization_guard = value_optimization();
612        transform(value)
613    }
614
615    /// Deprecated original name of [`Value::from_serialize`].
616    ///
617    /// This method was replaced by the more generic method [`Value::from_serialize`]
618    /// which also takes values by either reference or value.
619    #[deprecated(
620        since = "1.0.17",
621        note = "this method was replaced by Value::from_serialize"
622    )]
623    pub fn from_serializable<T: Serialize>(value: &T) -> Value {
624        let _serialization_guard = mark_internal_serialization();
625        let _optimization_guard = value_optimization();
626        transform(value)
627    }
628
629    /// Creates a value from an iterator.
630    ///
631    /// This takes an iterator (yielding values that can be turned into a [`Value`])
632    /// and returns a value that can be iterated over.  Today this value looks a bit like
633    /// a sequence (and will pretend to be one) but this is misleading.  Such values are
634    /// actually objects implementing [`IteratorObject`] but due to backwards
635    /// compatibility reasons it's not possible to give them a distinct type.
636    ///
637    /// Iterators that implement [`ExactSizeIterator`] or have a matching lower and upper
638    /// bound on the [`Iterator::size_hint`] report a known `loop.length`.  Iterators that
639    /// do not fulfill these requirements will not.  The same is true for `revindex` and
640    /// similar properties.
641    ///
642    /// ```
643    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
644    /// let val = Value::make_one_shot_iterator(0..10);
645    /// ```
646    pub fn make_one_shot_iterator<I, T>(iter: I) -> Value
647    where
648        I: Iterator<Item = T> + Send + Sync + 'static,
649        T: Into<Value> + Send + Sync + 'static,
650    {
651        Value::from_object(SimpleIteratorObject(Mutex::new(iter.fuse())))
652    }
653
654    /// Deprecated alternative to [`Value::make_one_shot_iterator`].
655    #[deprecated(
656        since = "1.0.19",
657        note = "this method was replaced by Value::make_one_shot_iterator"
658    )]
659    pub fn from_iterator<I, T>(iter: I) -> Value
660    where
661        I: Iterator<Item = T> + Send + Sync + 'static,
662        T: Into<Value> + 'static,
663    {
664        Value::from_object(SimpleIteratorObject(Mutex::new(iter.fuse())))
665    }
666
667    /// Creates a value from a safe string.
668    ///
669    /// A safe string is one that will bypass auto escaping.  For instance if you
670    /// want to have the template engine render some HTML without the user having to
671    /// supply the `|safe` filter, you can use a value of this type instead.
672    ///
673    /// ```
674    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
675    /// let val = Value::from_safe_string("<em>note</em>".into());
676    /// ```
677    pub fn from_safe_string(value: String) -> Value {
678        ValueRepr::String(Arc::from(value), StringType::Safe).into()
679    }
680
681    /// Creates a value from a dynamic object.
682    ///
683    /// For more information see [`Object`].
684    ///
685    /// ```rust
686    /// # use minijinja::value::{Value, Object};
687    /// use std::fmt;
688    ///
689    /// #[derive(Debug)]
690    /// struct Thing {
691    ///     id: usize,
692    /// }
693    ///
694    /// impl fmt::Display for Thing {
695    ///     fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
696    ///         fmt::Debug::fmt(self, f)
697    ///     }
698    /// }
699    ///
700    /// impl Object for Thing {}
701    ///
702    /// let val = Value::from_object(Thing { id: 42 });
703    /// ```
704    ///
705    /// Objects are internally reference counted.  If you want to hold on to the
706    /// `Arc` you can directly create the value from an arc'ed object:
707    ///
708    /// ```rust
709    /// # use minijinja::value::{Value, Object};
710    /// # #[derive(Debug)]
711    /// # struct Thing { id: usize };
712    /// # impl std::fmt::Display for Thing {
713    /// #     fn fmt(&self, f: &mut std::fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> std::fmt::Result {
714    /// #         todo!();
715    /// #     }
716    /// # }
717    /// # impl Object for Thing {}
718    /// use std::sync::Arc;
719    /// let val = Value::from(Arc::new(Thing { id: 42 }));
720    /// ```
721    pub fn from_object<T: Object>(value: T) -> Value {
722        Value::from(Arc::new(value) as Arc<dyn Object>)
723    }
724
725    /// Creates a value from an owned [`SeqObject`].
726    ///
727    /// This is a simplified API for creating dynamic sequences
728    /// without having to implement the entire [`Object`] protocol.
729    pub fn from_seq_object<T: SeqObject + 'static>(value: T) -> Value {
730        Value::from_object(SimpleSeqObject(value))
731    }
732
733    /// Creates a value from an owned [`StructObject`].
734    ///
735    /// This is a simplified API for creating dynamic structs
736    /// without having to implement the entire [`Object`] protocol.
737    pub fn from_struct_object<T: StructObject + 'static>(value: T) -> Value {
738        Value::from_object(SimpleStructObject(value))
739    }
740
741    /// Creates a callable value from a function.
742    ///
743    /// ```
744    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
745    /// let pow = Value::from_function(|a: u32| a * a);
746    /// ```
747    pub fn from_function<F, Rv, Args>(f: F) -> Value
748    where
749        // the crazy bounds here exist to enable borrowing in closures
750        F: functions::Function<Rv, Args>
751            + for<'a> functions::Function<Rv, <Args as FunctionArgs<'a>>::Output>,
752        Rv: FunctionResult,
753        Args: for<'a> FunctionArgs<'a>,
754    {
755        functions::BoxedFunction::new(f).to_value()
756    }
757
758    /// Returns the kind of the value.
759    ///
760    /// This can be used to determine what's in the value before trying to
761    /// perform operations on it.
762    pub fn kind(&self) -> ValueKind {
763        match self.0 {
764            ValueRepr::Undefined => ValueKind::Undefined,
765            ValueRepr::Bool(_) => ValueKind::Bool,
766            ValueRepr::U64(_) | ValueRepr::I64(_) | ValueRepr::F64(_) => ValueKind::Number,
767            ValueRepr::None => ValueKind::None,
768            ValueRepr::I128(_) => ValueKind::Number,
769            ValueRepr::String(..) => ValueKind::String,
770            ValueRepr::Bytes(_) => ValueKind::Bytes,
771            ValueRepr::U128(_) => ValueKind::Number,
772            ValueRepr::Seq(_) => ValueKind::Seq,
773            ValueRepr::Map(..) => ValueKind::Map,
774            // XXX: invalid values report themselves as maps which is a lie
775            ValueRepr::Invalid(_) => ValueKind::Map,
776            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
777                // XXX: basic objects should probably not report as map and
778                // iterators should report as a new iterator value type.
779                ObjectKind::Plain => ValueKind::Map,
780                ObjectKind::Seq(_) => ValueKind::Seq,
781                ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => ValueKind::Seq,
782                ObjectKind::Struct(_) => ValueKind::Map,
783            },
784        }
785    }
786
787    /// Returns `true` if the value is a number.
788    ///
789    /// To convert a value into a primitive number, use [`TryFrom`] or [`TryInto`].
790    pub fn is_number(&self) -> bool {
791        matches!(
792            self.0,
793            ValueRepr::U64(_)
794                | ValueRepr::I64(_)
795                | ValueRepr::F64(_)
796                | ValueRepr::I128(_)
797                | ValueRepr::U128(_)
798        )
799    }
800
801    /// Returns `true` if the map represents keyword arguments.
802    pub fn is_kwargs(&self) -> bool {
803        matches!(self.0, ValueRepr::Map(_, MapType::Kwargs))
804    }
805
806    /// Is this value true?
807    pub fn is_true(&self) -> bool {
808        match self.0 {
809            ValueRepr::Bool(val) => val,
810            ValueRepr::U64(x) => x != 0,
811            ValueRepr::U128(x) => x.0 != 0,
812            ValueRepr::I64(x) => x != 0,
813            ValueRepr::I128(x) => x.0 != 0,
814            ValueRepr::F64(x) => x != 0.0,
815            ValueRepr::String(ref x, _) => !x.is_empty(),
816            ValueRepr::Bytes(ref x) => !x.is_empty(),
817            ValueRepr::None | ValueRepr::Undefined | ValueRepr::Invalid(_) => false,
818            ValueRepr::Seq(ref x) => !x.is_empty(),
819            ValueRepr::Map(ref x, _) => !x.is_empty(),
820            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref x) => match x.kind() {
821                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => true,
822                ObjectKind::Seq(s) => s.item_count() != 0,
823                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => s.field_count() != 0,
824            },
825        }
826    }
827
828    /// Returns `true` if this value is safe.
829    pub fn is_safe(&self) -> bool {
830        matches!(&self.0, ValueRepr::String(_, StringType::Safe))
831    }
832
833    /// Returns `true` if this value is undefined.
834    pub fn is_undefined(&self) -> bool {
835        matches!(&self.0, ValueRepr::Undefined)
836    }
837
838    /// Returns `true` if this value is none.
839    pub fn is_none(&self) -> bool {
840        matches!(&self.0, ValueRepr::None)
841    }
842
843    /// If the value is a string, return it.
844    pub fn as_str(&self) -> Option<&str> {
845        match &self.0 {
846            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => Some(s as &str),
847            _ => None,
848        }
849    }
850
851    /// Returns the bytes of this value if they exist.
852    pub fn as_bytes(&self) -> Option<&[u8]> {
853        match &self.0 {
854            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => Some(s.as_bytes()),
855            ValueRepr::Bytes(ref b) => Some(&b[..]),
856            _ => None,
857        }
858    }
859
860    /// If the value is an object, it's returned as [`Object`].
861    pub fn as_object(&self) -> Option<&dyn Object> {
862        match self.0 {
863            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => Some(&**dy as &dyn Object),
864            _ => None,
865        }
866    }
867
868    /// If the value is a sequence it's returned as [`SeqObject`].
869    pub fn as_seq(&self) -> Option<&dyn SeqObject> {
870        match self.0 {
871            ValueRepr::Seq(ref v) => return Some(&**v as &dyn SeqObject),
872            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => {
873                if let ObjectKind::Seq(seq) = dy.kind() {
874                    return Some(seq);
875                }
876            }
877            _ => {}
878        }
879        None
880    }
881
882    /// If the value is a struct, return it as [`StructObject`].
883    pub fn as_struct(&self) -> Option<&dyn StructObject> {
884        if let ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) = self.0 {
885            if let ObjectKind::Struct(s) = dy.kind() {
886                return Some(s);
887            }
888        }
889        None
890    }
891
892    /// Returns the length of the contained value.
893    ///
894    /// Values without a length will return `None`.
895    ///
896    /// ```
897    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
898    /// let seq = Value::from(vec![1, 2, 3, 4]);
899    /// assert_eq!(seq.len(), Some(4));
900    /// ```
901    pub fn len(&self) -> Option<usize> {
902        match self.0 {
903            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => Some(s.chars().count()),
904            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => Some(items.len()),
905            ValueRepr::Seq(ref items) => Some(items.len()),
906            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
907                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => None,
908                ObjectKind::Seq(s) => Some(s.item_count()),
909                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => Some(s.field_count()),
910            },
911            _ => None,
912        }
913    }
914
915    /// Looks up an attribute by attribute name.
916    ///
917    /// This this returns [`UNDEFINED`](Self::UNDEFINED) when an invalid key is
918    /// resolved.  An error is returned when if the value does not contain an object
919    /// that has attributes.
920    ///
921    /// ```
922    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
923    /// # fn test() -> Result<(), minijinja::Error> {
924    /// let ctx = minijinja::context! {
925    ///     foo => "Foo"
926    /// };
927    /// let value = ctx.get_attr("foo")?;
928    /// assert_eq!(value.to_string(), "Foo");
929    /// # Ok(()) }
930    /// ```
931    pub fn get_attr(&self, key: &str) -> Result<Value, Error> {
932        Ok(match self.0 {
933            ValueRepr::Undefined => return Err(Error::from(ErrorKind::UndefinedError)),
934            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => items.get(&KeyRef::Str(key)).cloned(),
935            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
936                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => s.get_field(key),
937                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Seq(_) | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => None,
938            },
939            _ => None,
940        }
941        .unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED))
942    }
943
944    /// Alternative lookup strategy without error handling exclusively for context
945    /// resolution.
946    ///
947    /// The main difference is that the return value will be `None` if the value is
948    /// unable to look up the key rather than returning `Undefined` and errors will
949    /// also not be created.
950    pub(crate) fn get_attr_fast(&self, key: &str) -> Option<Value> {
951        match self.0 {
952            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => items.get(&KeyRef::Str(key)).cloned(),
953            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
954                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => s.get_field(key),
955                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Seq(_) | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => None,
956            },
957            _ => None,
958        }
959    }
960
961    /// Looks up an index of the value.
962    ///
963    /// This is a shortcut for [`get_item`](Self::get_item).
964    ///
965    /// ```
966    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
967    /// let seq = Value::from(vec![0u32, 1, 2]);
968    /// let value = seq.get_item_by_index(1).unwrap();
969    /// assert_eq!(value.try_into().ok(), Some(1));
970    /// ```
971    pub fn get_item_by_index(&self, idx: usize) -> Result<Value, Error> {
972        self.get_item(&Value(ValueRepr::U64(idx as _)))
973    }
974
975    /// Looks up an item (or attribute) by key.
976    ///
977    /// This is similar to [`get_attr`](Self::get_attr) but instead of using
978    /// a string key this can be any key.  For instance this can be used to
979    /// index into sequences.  Like [`get_attr`](Self::get_attr) this returns
980    /// [`UNDEFINED`](Self::UNDEFINED) when an invalid key is looked up.
981    ///
982    /// ```
983    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
984    /// let ctx = minijinja::context! {
985    ///     foo => "Foo",
986    /// };
987    /// let value = ctx.get_item(&Value::from("foo")).unwrap();
988    /// assert_eq!(value.to_string(), "Foo");
989    /// ```
990    pub fn get_item(&self, key: &Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
991        if let ValueRepr::Undefined = self.0 {
992            Err(Error::from(ErrorKind::UndefinedError))
993        } else {
994            Ok(self.get_item_opt(key).unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED))
995        }
996    }
997
998    /// Iterates over the value.
999    ///
1000    /// Depending on the [`kind`](Self::kind) of the value the iterator
1001    /// has a different behavior.
1002    ///
1003    /// * [`ValueKind::Map`]: the iterator yields the keys of the map.
1004    /// * [`ValueKind::Seq`]: the iterator yields the items in the sequence.
1005    /// * [`ValueKind::None`] / [`ValueKind::Undefined`]: the iterator is empty.
1006    ///
1007    /// ```
1008    /// # use minijinja::value::Value;
1009    /// # fn test() -> Result<(), minijinja::Error> {
1010    /// let value = Value::from({
1011    ///     let mut m = std::collections::BTreeMap::new();
1012    ///     m.insert("foo", 42);
1013    ///     m.insert("bar", 23);
1014    ///     m
1015    /// });
1016    /// for key in value.try_iter()? {
1017    ///     let value = value.get_item(&key)?;
1018    ///     println!("{} = {}", key, value);
1019    /// }
1020    /// # Ok(()) }
1021    /// ```
1022    pub fn try_iter(&self) -> Result<ValueIter<'_>, Error> {
1023        self.try_iter_owned().map(|inner| ValueIter {
1024            _marker: PhantomData,
1025            inner,
1026        })
1027    }
1028
1029    /// Returns some reference to the boxed object if it is of type `T`, or None if it isnt.
1030    ///
1031    /// This is basically the "reverse" of [`from_object`](Self::from_object),
1032    /// [`from_seq_object`](Self::from_seq_object) and [`from_struct_object`](Self::from_struct_object).
1033    /// It's also a shortcut for [`downcast_ref`](trait.Object.html#method.downcast_ref)
1034    /// on the return value of [`as_object`](Self::as_object).
1035    ///
1036    /// # Example
1037    ///
1038    /// ```rust
1039    /// # use minijinja::value::{Value, Object};
1040    /// use std::fmt;
1041    ///
1042    /// #[derive(Debug)]
1043    /// struct Thing {
1044    ///     id: usize,
1045    /// }
1046    ///
1047    /// impl fmt::Display for Thing {
1048    ///     fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
1049    ///         fmt::Debug::fmt(self, f)
1050    ///     }
1051    /// }
1052    ///
1053    /// impl Object for Thing {}
1054    ///
1055    /// let x_value = Value::from_object(Thing { id: 42 });
1056    /// let thing = x_value.downcast_object_ref::<Thing>().unwrap();
1057    /// assert_eq!(thing.id, 42);
1058    /// ```
1059    ///
1060    /// It also works with [`SeqObject`] or [`StructObject`]:
1061    ///
1062    /// ```rust
1063    /// # use minijinja::value::{Value, SeqObject};
1064    ///
1065    /// struct Thing {
1066    ///     id: usize,
1067    /// }
1068    ///
1069    /// impl SeqObject for Thing {
1070    ///     fn get_item(&self, idx: usize) -> Option<Value> {
1071    ///         (idx < 3).then(|| Value::from(idx))
1072    ///     }
1073    ///     fn item_count(&self) -> usize {
1074    ///         3
1075    ///     }
1076    /// }
1077    ///
1078    /// let x_value = Value::from_seq_object(Thing { id: 42 });
1079    /// let thing = x_value.downcast_object_ref::<Thing>().unwrap();
1080    /// assert_eq!(thing.id, 42);
1081    /// ```
1082    pub fn downcast_object_ref<T: 'static>(&self) -> Option<&T> {
1083        self.as_object().and_then(|x| x.downcast_ref())
1084    }
1085
1086    pub(crate) fn get_item_opt(&self, key: &Value) -> Option<Value> {
1087        let key = KeyRef::Value(key.clone());
1088
1089        let seq = match self.0 {
1090            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => return items.get(&key).cloned(),
1091            ValueRepr::Seq(ref items) => &**items as &dyn SeqObject,
1092            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
1093                ObjectKind::Plain | ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => return None,
1094                ObjectKind::Seq(s) => s,
1095                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => {
1096                    return if let Some(key) = key.as_str() {
1097                        s.get_field(key)
1098                    } else {
1099                        None
1100                    };
1101                }
1102            },
1103            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => {
1104                if let Some(idx) = key.as_i64() {
1105                    let idx = some!(isize::try_from(idx).ok());
1106                    let idx = if idx < 0 {
1107                        some!(s.chars().count().checked_sub(-idx as usize))
1108                    } else {
1109                        idx as usize
1110                    };
1111                    return s.chars().nth(idx).map(Value::from);
1112                } else {
1113                    return None;
1114                }
1115            }
1116            _ => return None,
1117        };
1118
1119        if let Some(idx) = key.as_i64() {
1120            let idx = some!(isize::try_from(idx).ok());
1121            let idx = if idx < 0 {
1122                some!(seq.item_count().checked_sub(-idx as usize))
1123            } else {
1124                idx as usize
1125            };
1126            seq.get_item(idx)
1127        } else {
1128            None
1129        }
1130    }
1131
1132    /// Calls the value directly.
1133    ///
1134    /// If the value holds a function or macro, this invokes it.  Note that in
1135    /// MiniJinja there is a separate namespace for methods on objects and callable
1136    /// items.  To call methods (which should be a rather rare occurrence) you
1137    /// have to use [`call_method`](Self::call_method).
1138    ///
1139    /// The `args` slice is for the arguments of the function call.  To pass
1140    /// keyword arguments use the [`Kwargs`] type.
1141    ///
1142    /// Usually the state is already available when it's useful to call this method,
1143    /// but when it's not available you can get a fresh template state straight
1144    /// from the [`Template`](crate::Template) via [`new_state`](crate::Template::new_state).
1145    ///
1146    /// ```
1147    /// # use minijinja::{Environment, value::{Value, Kwargs}};
1148    /// # let mut env = Environment::new();
1149    /// # env.add_template("foo", "").unwrap();
1150    /// # let tmpl = env.get_template("foo").unwrap();
1151    /// # let state = tmpl.new_state(); let state = &state;
1152    /// let func = Value::from_function(|v: i64, kwargs: Kwargs| {
1153    ///     v * kwargs.get::<i64>("mult").unwrap_or(1)
1154    /// });
1155    /// let rv = func.call(
1156    ///     state,
1157    ///     &[
1158    ///         Value::from(42),
1159    ///         Value::from(Kwargs::from_iter([("mult", Value::from(2))])),
1160    ///     ],
1161    /// ).unwrap();
1162    /// assert_eq!(rv, Value::from(84));
1163    /// ```
1164    ///
1165    /// With the [`args!`](crate::args) macro creating an argument slice is
1166    /// simplified:
1167    ///
1168    /// ```
1169    /// # use minijinja::{Environment, args, value::{Value, Kwargs}};
1170    /// # let mut env = Environment::new();
1171    /// # env.add_template("foo", "").unwrap();
1172    /// # let tmpl = env.get_template("foo").unwrap();
1173    /// # let state = tmpl.new_state(); let state = &state;
1174    /// let func = Value::from_function(|v: i64, kwargs: Kwargs| {
1175    ///     v * kwargs.get::<i64>("mult").unwrap_or(1)
1176    /// });
1177    /// let rv = func.call(state, args!(42, mult => 2)).unwrap();
1178    /// assert_eq!(rv, Value::from(84));
1179    /// ```
1180    pub fn call(&self, state: &State, args: &[Value]) -> Result<Value, Error> {
1181        if let ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) = self.0 {
1182            dy.call(state, args)
1183        } else {
1184            Err(Error::new(
1185                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
1186                format!("value of type {} is not callable", self.kind()),
1187            ))
1188        }
1189    }
1190
1191    /// Calls a method on the value.
1192    ///
1193    /// The name of the method is `name`, the arguments passed are in the `args`
1194    /// slice.
1195    pub fn call_method(&self, state: &State, name: &str, args: &[Value]) -> Result<Value, Error> {
1196        match self._call_method(state, name, args) {
1197            Ok(rv) => Ok(rv),
1198            Err(err) => {
1199                if err.kind() == ErrorKind::UnknownMethod {
1200                    if let Some(ref callback) = state.env().unknown_method_callback {
1201                        return callback(state, self, name, args);
1202                    }
1203                }
1204                Err(err)
1205            }
1206        }
1207    }
1208
1209    fn _call_method(&self, state: &State, name: &str, args: &[Value]) -> Result<Value, Error> {
1210        match self.0 {
1211            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => return dy.call_method(state, name, args),
1212            ValueRepr::Map(ref map, _) => {
1213                if let Some(value) = map.get(&KeyRef::Str(name)) {
1214                    return value.call(state, args);
1215                }
1216            }
1217            _ => {}
1218        }
1219        Err(Error::new(
1220            ErrorKind::UnknownMethod,
1221            format!("object has no method named {name}"),
1222        ))
1223    }
1224
1225    /// Iterates over the value without holding a reference.
1226    pub(crate) fn try_iter_owned(&self) -> Result<OwnedValueIterator, Error> {
1227        let (iter_state, len) = match self.0 {
1228            ValueRepr::None | ValueRepr::Undefined => (ValueIteratorState::Empty, Some(0)),
1229            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => (
1230                ValueIteratorState::Chars(0, Arc::clone(s)),
1231                Some(s.chars().count()),
1232            ),
1233            ValueRepr::Seq(ref seq) => {
1234                (ValueIteratorState::Seq(0, Arc::clone(seq)), Some(seq.len()))
1235            }
1236            #[cfg(feature = "preserve_order")]
1237            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => (
1238                ValueIteratorState::Map(0, Arc::clone(items)),
1239                Some(items.len()),
1240            ),
1241            #[cfg(not(feature = "preserve_order"))]
1242            ValueRepr::Map(ref items, _) => (
1243                ValueIteratorState::Map(
1244                    items.iter().next().map(|x| x.0.clone()),
1245                    Arc::clone(items),
1246                ),
1247                Some(items.len()),
1248            ),
1249            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref obj) => {
1250                match obj.kind() {
1251                    ObjectKind::Plain => (ValueIteratorState::Empty, Some(0)),
1252                    ObjectKind::Seq(s) => (
1253                        ValueIteratorState::DynSeq(0, Arc::clone(obj)),
1254                        Some(s.item_count()),
1255                    ),
1256                    ObjectKind::Struct(s) => {
1257                        // the assumption is that structs don't have excessive field counts
1258                        // and that most iterations go over all fields, so creating a
1259                        // temporary vector here is acceptable.
1260                        if let Some(fields) = s.static_fields() {
1261                            (ValueIteratorState::StaticStr(0, fields), Some(fields.len()))
1262                        } else {
1263                            let attrs = s.fields();
1264                            let attr_count = attrs.len();
1265                            (ValueIteratorState::ArcStr(0, attrs), Some(attr_count))
1266                        }
1267                    }
1268                    ObjectKind::Iterator(_) => {
1269                        (ValueIteratorState::Iterator(Arc::clone(obj)), None)
1270                    }
1271                }
1272            }
1273            _ => {
1274                return Err(Error::new(
1275                    ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
1276                    format!("{} is not iterable", self.kind()),
1277                ))
1278            }
1279        };
1280        Ok(OwnedValueIterator { iter_state, len })
1281    }
1282
1283    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1284    pub(crate) fn get_path(&self, path: &str) -> Result<Value, Error> {
1285        let mut rv = self.clone();
1286        for part in path.split('.') {
1287            if let Ok(num) = part.parse::<usize>() {
1288                rv = ok!(rv.get_item_by_index(num));
1289            } else {
1290                rv = ok!(rv.get_attr(part));
1291            }
1292        }
1293        Ok(rv)
1294    }
1295}
1296
1297impl Serialize for Value {
1298    fn serialize<S>(&self, serializer: S) -> Result<S::Ok, S::Error>
1299    where
1300        S: Serializer,
1301    {
1302        // enable round tripping of values
1303        if serializing_for_value() {
1304            let handle = LAST_VALUE_HANDLE.with(|x| {
1305                // we are okay with overflowing the handle here because these values only
1306                // live for a very short period of time and it's not likely that you run out
1307                // of an entire u32 worth of handles in a single serialization operation.
1308                // This lets us stick the handle into a unit variant in the serde data model.
1309                let rv = x.get().wrapping_add(1);
1310                x.set(rv);
1311                rv
1312            });
1313            VALUE_HANDLES.with(|handles| handles.borrow_mut().insert(handle, self.clone()));
1314            return serializer.serialize_unit_variant(
1315                VALUE_HANDLE_MARKER,
1316                handle,
1317                VALUE_HANDLE_MARKER,
1318            );
1319        }
1320
1321        match self.0 {
1322            ValueRepr::Bool(b) => serializer.serialize_bool(b),
1323            ValueRepr::U64(u) => serializer.serialize_u64(u),
1324            ValueRepr::I64(i) => serializer.serialize_i64(i),
1325            ValueRepr::F64(f) => serializer.serialize_f64(f),
1326            ValueRepr::None | ValueRepr::Undefined | ValueRepr::Invalid(_) => {
1327                serializer.serialize_unit()
1328            }
1329            ValueRepr::U128(u) => serializer.serialize_u128(u.0),
1330            ValueRepr::I128(i) => serializer.serialize_i128(i.0),
1331            ValueRepr::String(ref s, _) => serializer.serialize_str(s),
1332            ValueRepr::Bytes(ref b) => serializer.serialize_bytes(b),
1333            ValueRepr::Seq(ref elements) => elements.serialize(serializer),
1334            ValueRepr::Map(ref entries, _) => {
1335                use serde::ser::SerializeMap;
1336                let mut map = ok!(serializer.serialize_map(Some(entries.len())));
1337                for (ref k, ref v) in entries.iter() {
1338                    ok!(map.serialize_entry(k, v));
1339                }
1340                map.end()
1341            }
1342            ValueRepr::Dynamic(ref dy) => match dy.kind() {
1343                ObjectKind::Plain => serializer.serialize_str(&dy.to_string()),
1344                ObjectKind::Seq(s) => {
1345                    use serde::ser::SerializeSeq;
1346                    let mut seq = ok!(serializer.serialize_seq(Some(s.item_count())));
1347                    for item in s.iter() {
1348                        ok!(seq.serialize_element(&item));
1349                    }
1350                    seq.end()
1351                }
1352                ObjectKind::Struct(s) => {
1353                    use serde::ser::SerializeMap;
1354                    let mut map = ok!(serializer.serialize_map(None));
1355                    if let Some(fields) = s.static_fields() {
1356                        for k in fields {
1357                            let v = s.get_field(k).unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED);
1358                            ok!(map.serialize_entry(k, &v));
1359                        }
1360                    } else {
1361                        for k in s.fields() {
1362                            let v = s.get_field(&k).unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED);
1363                            ok!(map.serialize_entry(&*k as &str, &v));
1364                        }
1365                    }
1366                    map.end()
1367                }
1368                ObjectKind::Iterator(i) => {
1369                    use serde::ser::SerializeSeq;
1370                    let mut seq = ok!(serializer.serialize_seq(None));
1371                    while let Some(value) = i.next_value() {
1372                        ok!(seq.serialize_element(&value));
1373                    }
1374                    seq.end()
1375                }
1376            },
1377        }
1378    }
1379}
1380
1381/// Iterates over a value.
1382pub struct ValueIter<'a> {
1383    _marker: PhantomData<&'a Value>,
1384    inner: OwnedValueIterator,
1385}
1386
1387impl<'a> Iterator for ValueIter<'a> {
1388    type Item = Value;
1389
1390    #[inline(always)]
1391    fn next(&mut self) -> Option<Self::Item> {
1392        self.inner.next()
1393    }
1394}
1395
1396pub(crate) struct OwnedValueIterator {
1397    iter_state: ValueIteratorState,
1398    len: Option<usize>,
1399}
1400
1401impl Iterator for OwnedValueIterator {
1402    type Item = Value;
1403
1404    fn next(&mut self) -> Option<Self::Item> {
1405        self.iter_state.advance_state().map(|x| {
1406            if let Some(ref mut len) = self.len {
1407                *len -= 1;
1408            }
1409            x
1410        })
1411    }
1412
1413    fn size_hint(&self) -> (usize, Option<usize>) {
1414        if let ValueIteratorState::Iterator(ref obj) = self.iter_state {
1415            if let ObjectKind::Iterator(iter) = obj.kind() {
1416                if let Some(len) = iter.iterator_len() {
1417                    return (len, Some(len));
1418                }
1419            }
1420        }
1421        (self.len.unwrap_or(0), self.len)
1422    }
1423}
1424
1425impl fmt::Debug for OwnedValueIterator {
1426    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
1427        f.debug_struct("ValueIterator").finish()
1428    }
1429}
1430
1431enum ValueIteratorState {
1432    Empty,
1433    Chars(usize, Arc<str>),
1434    Seq(usize, Arc<Vec<Value>>),
1435    StaticStr(usize, &'static [&'static str]),
1436    ArcStr(usize, Vec<Arc<str>>),
1437    DynSeq(usize, Arc<dyn Object>),
1438    #[cfg(not(feature = "preserve_order"))]
1439    Map(Option<KeyRef<'static>>, Arc<ValueMap>),
1440    #[cfg(feature = "preserve_order")]
1441    Map(usize, Arc<ValueMap>),
1442    Iterator(Arc<dyn Object>),
1443}
1444
1445impl ValueIteratorState {
1446    fn advance_state(&mut self) -> Option<Value> {
1447        match self {
1448            ValueIteratorState::Empty => None,
1449            ValueIteratorState::Chars(offset, ref s) => {
1450                (s as &str)[*offset..].chars().next().map(|c| {
1451                    *offset += c.len_utf8();
1452                    Value::from(c)
1453                })
1454            }
1455            ValueIteratorState::Seq(idx, items) => items
1456                .get(*idx)
1457                .map(|x| {
1458                    *idx += 1;
1459                    x
1460                })
1461                .cloned(),
1462            ValueIteratorState::StaticStr(idx, items) => items.get(*idx).map(|x| {
1463                *idx += 1;
1464                Value::from(intern(x))
1465            }),
1466            ValueIteratorState::ArcStr(idx, items) => items.get(*idx).map(|x| {
1467                *idx += 1;
1468                Value::from(x.clone())
1469            }),
1470            ValueIteratorState::DynSeq(idx, obj) => {
1471                if let ObjectKind::Seq(seq) = obj.kind() {
1472                    seq.get_item(*idx).map(|x| {
1473                        *idx += 1;
1474                        x
1475                    })
1476                } else {
1477                    unreachable!()
1478                }
1479            }
1480            #[cfg(feature = "preserve_order")]
1481            ValueIteratorState::Map(idx, map) => map.get_index(*idx).map(|x| {
1482                *idx += 1;
1483                x.0.as_value()
1484            }),
1485            #[cfg(not(feature = "preserve_order"))]
1486            ValueIteratorState::Map(ptr, map) => {
1487                if let Some(current) = ptr.take() {
1488                    let next = map.range(&current..).nth(1).map(|x| x.0.clone());
1489                    let rv = current.as_value();
1490                    *ptr = next;
1491                    Some(rv)
1492                } else {
1493                    None
1494                }
1495            }
1496            ValueIteratorState::Iterator(obj) => {
1497                if let ObjectKind::Iterator(iter) = obj.kind() {
1498                    iter.next_value()
1499                } else {
1500                    unreachable!()
1501                }
1502            }
1503        }
1504    }
1505}
1506
1507#[cfg(test)]
1508mod tests {
1509    use super::*;
1510
1511    use similar_asserts::assert_eq;
1512
1513    #[test]
1514    fn test_dynamic_object_roundtrip() {
1515        use std::sync::atomic::{self, AtomicUsize};
1516
1517        #[derive(Debug)]
1518        struct X(AtomicUsize);
1519
1520        impl fmt::Display for X {
1521            fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
1522                write!(f, "{}", self.0.load(atomic::Ordering::Relaxed))
1523            }
1524        }
1525
1526        impl Object for X {
1527            fn kind(&self) -> ObjectKind<'_> {
1528                ObjectKind::Struct(self)
1529            }
1530        }
1531
1532        impl crate::value::object::StructObject for X {
1533            fn get_field(&self, name: &str) -> Option<Value> {
1534                match name {
1535                    "value" => Some(Value::from(self.0.load(atomic::Ordering::Relaxed))),
1536                    _ => None,
1537                }
1538            }
1539
1540            fn static_fields(&self) -> Option<&'static [&'static str]> {
1541                Some(&["value"][..])
1542            }
1543        }
1544
1545        let x = Arc::new(X(Default::default()));
1546        let x_value = Value::from(x.clone());
1547        x.0.fetch_add(42, atomic::Ordering::Relaxed);
1548        let x_clone = Value::from_serialize(&x_value);
1549        x.0.fetch_add(23, atomic::Ordering::Relaxed);
1550
1551        assert_eq!(x_value.to_string(), "65");
1552        assert_eq!(x_clone.to_string(), "65");
1553    }
1554
1555    #[test]
1556    fn test_string_char() {
1557        let val = Value::from('a');
1558        assert_eq!(char::try_from(val).unwrap(), 'a');
1559        let val = Value::from("a");
1560        assert_eq!(char::try_from(val).unwrap(), 'a');
1561        let val = Value::from("wat");
1562        assert!(char::try_from(val).is_err());
1563    }
1564
1565    #[test]
1566    #[cfg(target_pointer_width = "64")]
1567    fn test_sizes() {
1568        assert_eq!(std::mem::size_of::<Value>(), 24);
1569    }
1570}
